awd_abstract_narration:
The UnKnot V Conference will be held at Seattle University in Seattle, WA on July 13-14th, 2024. UnKnot V, like the four undergraduate knot theory conferences that preceded it, will be a gathering of students who are interested in knot theory research together with their faculty and graduate student mentors. Participants who are new to knot theory and interested to learn more are also welcome to join in this community-building event. Accessible talks at UnKnot V will be given by world-renowned knot theory experts as well as students who are just beginning their work in this field. UnKnot V will also feature a mini workshop on using machine learning in knot theory research and one on recreational topology with the aim to inspire fun math outreach projects. 

Knot theory is an area of research which uses tools from and gives insight into many areas of mathematics, including topology, geometry, algebra, and combinatorics. There are important applications in knot theory to DNA knotting, synthetic chemistry, protein folding, and quantum computing as well as in anthropology, art, and materials science. Knot theory also lends itself to research by undergraduates since there are open problems that can be easily stated and explained but lead to mathematics with great depth. The focus of UnKnot V will be on research that has been done by undergraduates and on open problems amenable to research by students. Since experts will be brought together with the students and faculty who would like to do research in this field, this unique conference structure will allow for vertical integration from undergraduates and graduate students to faculty who are interested in mentoring students in knot theory research and experts in the field. Many opportunities for research projects will be presented. The conference webpage is: https://sites.google.com/view/unknot-v-conference/home.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Mathematical and Physical Sciences

por.por_cntn:
The UnKnot V Conference was hosted at Seattle University on July 13-14, 2024. UnKnot V was a vertically-integrated gathering of 76 mathematicians: 44 undergraduates, 8 graduate students, and 24 faculty. The conference included 10 invited faculty talks, a featured undergraduate talk, 18 contributed talks by students and faculty, and two workshops. The focus of this conference was on research that has been done by undergraduates and on open problems amenable to research by undergraduates. In addition to presentations, there were other community-building events for all participants. Participants had the opportunity to learn how to 3D print knotted surfaces, learn how to perform magic rope tricks, perform mathematical plays in the park over pizza, win prizes, and meet new friends through a knot-themed ice breaker game. An open problem session was held as the closing event of the conference. 

According to a post-survey given to participants, nearly all conference-goers said UnKnot V helped them feel more connected to the knot theory community (with only one participant reporting no change in how connected they felt). Participants reported feeling more supported in their research activites and excited about new ideas and potential collaborations as a result of attending the conference. For many at the UnKnot conference, this was their first opportunity to give a conference talk and network with other researchers beyond their research programs and home institutions. UnKnot V was an impactful professional development opportunity for people in the next generation of mathematics researchers!


Last Modified: 10/15/2024
Modified by: Allison Henrich
